title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0001
text: What is a distributed transaction in microservices?

options.text: A transaction that spans multiple services or databases
A transaction confined to a single database
A transaction that only updates cache
A transaction that runs on a single thread

explanation: Distributed transactions involve multiple services or databases that must maintain data consistency across boundaries.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0002
text: Why are distributed transactions challenging in microservices?

options.text: Because services are autonomous and have separate databases
Because all services share the same schema
Because microservices use a single database

explanation: Each microservice manages its own data, making it difficult to coordinate transactions across boundaries.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0003
text: Which of the following protocols is traditionally used for distributed transactions?
explanation: The Two-Phase Commit (2PC) protocol is a traditional approach to ensure atomicity in distributed transactions.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0004
text: What is the main drawback of using Two-Phase Commit (2PC) in microservices?

options.text: It introduces blocking and reduces availability

explanation: 2PC can block resources and reduce system availability, making it unsuitable for highly distributed systems.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0005
text: Which pattern is commonly used in microservices to handle distributed transactions?
explanation: The Saga pattern is widely used to manage distributed transactions through a series of local transactions and compensations.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0006
text: What is the main idea behind the Saga pattern?

options.text: Breaking a distributed transaction into a sequence of local transactions
Using a single global transaction manager
Centralizing all data in one database
Using synchronous communication for all services

explanation: The Saga pattern decomposes a distributed transaction into smaller local transactions coordinated through events or commands.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0007
text: Which of the following is a type of Saga implementation?
explanation: Choreography-based Sagas use events to coordinate transactions among services without a central controller.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0008
text: What is the other common type of Saga implementation besides choreography?
explanation: Orchestration-based Sagas use a central coordinator to manage the sequence of local transactions.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0009
text: In a choreography-based Saga, how do services communicate?
explanation: In choreography-based Sagas, services communicate asynchronously through events.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0010
text: In an orchestration-based Saga, what is the role of the orchestrator?

options.text: To coordinate and trigger local transactions in sequence

explanation: The orchestrator coordinates the execution of local transactions and compensations in an orchestration-based Saga.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0011
text: What is a compensating transaction in the Saga pattern?

options.text: A transaction that undoes the effects of a previous transaction
A transaction that retries failed operations
A transaction that commits all changes

explanation: Compensating transactions are used to undo the effects of previous successful transactions when a failure occurs later in the Saga.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0012
text: Which of the following is a key benefit of the Saga pattern?

options.text: It avoids global locks and blocking
It requires a global transaction manager

explanation: The Saga pattern avoids global locks and blocking by using local transactions and compensations.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0013
text: Which of the following is a drawback of the Saga pattern?
explanation: Designing compensating transactions can be complex because each service must handle rollback logic.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0014
text: What type of consistency does the Saga pattern provide?
explanation: The Saga pattern provides eventual consistency, meaning data becomes consistent after all transactions complete.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0015
text: Which of the following is a key challenge in distributed transactions?
explanation: Ensuring atomicity across multiple services is difficult because each service manages its own data.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0016
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using distributed transactions?
explanation: Distributed transactions help maintain data consistency across multiple services and databases.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0017
text: Which of the following is a drawback of distributed transactions?
explanation: Distributed transactions add complexity due to coordination and potential network failures.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0018
text: Which of the following is a common alternative to distributed transactions in microservices?
explanation: Event-driven eventual consistency is often used instead of distributed transactions to maintain data integrity asynchronously.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0019
text: What is the main goal of distributed transactions?

options.text: To ensure data consistency across multiple services

explanation: Distributed transactions aim to maintain data consistency across multiple services and databases.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0020
text: Which of the following best describes distributed transactions in microservices?

options.text: Transactions that span multiple services and databases
Transactions confined to a single service
Transactions that run on a single thread

explanation: Distributed transactions involve multiple services or databases that must maintain data consistency across boundaries.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0021
text: Which of the following is a key property that distributed transactions aim to maintain?
explanation: Atomicity ensures that all parts of a distributed transaction either complete successfully or none do.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0022
text: Which of the following is a common issue in distributed transactions?
explanation: Network latency and partial failures can disrupt distributed transactions across services.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0023
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Saga pattern over 2PC?
explanation: Sagas are non-blocking and more resilient than 2PC, which can block resources.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0024
text: What is the main disadvantage of Two-Phase Commit (2PC)?

options.text: It can block resources and reduce availability

explanation: 2PC can block resources and reduce system availability, making it unsuitable for microservices.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0025
text: Which of the following is a key difference between orchestration and choreography in Sagas?

options.text: Orchestration uses a central coordinator; choreography uses events
Choreography uses a central coordinator; orchestration uses events

explanation: Orchestration uses a central coordinator, while choreography relies on event-based communication.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0026
text: Which of the following is a challenge in implementing compensating transactions?

options.text: Designing logic to undo previous actions

explanation: Compensating transactions require careful design to reverse previous successful operations.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0027
text: Which of the following is a benefit of eventual consistency in distributed systems?
explanation: Eventual consistency improves availability and scalability by avoiding global locks.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0028
text: Which of the following is a common tool for implementing distributed transactions?

options.text: Kafka or RabbitMQ for event coordination

explanation: Event brokers like Kafka or RabbitMQ are often used to coordinate distributed transactions asynchronously.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0029
text: What is the main goal of distributed transactions?

options.text: To maintain data consistency across multiple services

explanation: Distributed transactions ensure data consistency across multiple services and databases.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0030
text: Which of the following is a key challenge in distributed transactions?
explanation: Partial failures can occur when one service succeeds and another fails, complicating rollback.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0031
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using the Saga pattern?
explanation: Sagas improve fault tolerance and decoupling by using local transactions and compensations.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0032
text: Which of the following is a drawback of distributed transactions?
explanation: Distributed transactions increase latency and complexity due to coordination overhead.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0033
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using asynchronous communication in distributed transactions?
explanation: Asynchronous communication improves scalability and decoupling in distributed systems.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0034
text: Which of the following is a key principle of distributed transactions?
explanation: Distributed transactions aim to maintain ACID properties across multiple systems.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0035
text: Which of the following is a common alternative to 2PC in microservices?
explanation: The Saga pattern is a common alternative to 2PC for managing distributed transactions.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0036
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using event-driven architecture for distributed transactions?
explanation: Event-driven architecture improves decoupling and fault tolerance in distributed transactions.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0037
text: Which of the following is a challenge in distributed transactions?

options.text: Ensuring atomicity and consistency across services

explanation: Ensuring atomicity and consistency across multiple services is a major challenge in distributed transactions.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0038
text: Which of the following is a benefit of distributed transactions for data integrity?

options.text: Ensures consistent data across multiple services

explanation: Distributed transactions ensure data integrity by maintaining consistency across services.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0039
text: Which of the following is a drawback of distributed transactions for performance?
explanation: Distributed transactions can increase latency due to coordination between services.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0040
text: Which of the following is a benefit of distributed transactions for reliability?

options.text: Ensures data consistency even in partial failures

explanation: Distributed transactions maintain reliability by ensuring data consistency even during partial failures.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0041
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using compensating transactions?

options.text: Allows rollback of completed steps in case of failure

explanation: Compensating transactions allow rollback of completed steps when a failure occurs later in the process.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0042
text: Which of the following is a challenge of distributed transactions for scalability?
explanation: Coordinating transactions across multiple services can limit scalability.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0043
text: Which of the following is a benefit of distributed transactions for consistency?
explanation: Distributed transactions ensure consistent state across multiple services and databases.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0044

options.text: Increased coordination and error handling complexity

explanation: Distributed transactions increase complexity due to coordination and error handling requirements.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0045

explanation: Distributed transactions ensure atomic updates across multiple services to maintain data integrity.

title: MicroserviceDistributedTransactions - Q0046
text: Which of the following is a benefit of distributed transactions for fault tolerance?
explanation: Distributed transactions can recover from partial failures using compensating transactions.
